tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This is an exclamation that should be translated with whatever exclamation of emphasis you have in your language to make it sound natural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
the God who is greater than the gods that other people worship (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
That is, because he is wise.

tn.ref: spread out the earth above the waters
tn.text: The ancient Israelites thought that the earth's dry land was on top of the sea. AT: "placed the earth over the waters"
This is a reference to the sources of light for the earth, especially the sun and the moon. AT: "the sun and the moon and the stars"

tn.ref: to rule by day ... to rule by night
tn.text: The sun, moon, and stars are spoken of as if they were kings. AT: "to mark the time of day ... to mark the time of night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: with a strong hand and a raised arm
tn.text: Here "hand" and "arm" represent power. AT: "with great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The soldiers of Pharaoh drowned in the Sea of Reeds.
Here defeat is spoken of as if it were tipping someone over. AT: "defeated Pharaoh" or "defeated the king of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
That is, the army of Pharaoh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These kings were just two of the many kings that God enabled the Israelites to defeat. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

The condition of feeling shame is spoken of as if it were a place that the Israelites had been in. This is a reference to the many times when the Israelites' enemies had defeated them in battle and shamed them. AT: "cared when we were shamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: has given us victory over our enemies
tn.text: Causing people to be victorious and defeat their enemies is spoken of as giving them victory, as if victory were an object that can be given. AT: "has made us victorious over our enemies" or "has made us able to defeat our enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the God who lives in heaven" or "the God whom the heavenly beings worship"
